posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

What is your favorite voodoo loa, /his/?

>Lwa (pronounced lwah), also called loa or loi, are spirits in the African diasporic religion of Haitian Vodou. They have also been incorporated into some revivalist forms of Louisiana Voodoo. Many of the lwa derive their identities in part from deities venerated in the traditional religions of West Africa, especially those of the Fon and Yoruba

>In Haitian Vodou, the lwa serve as intermediaries between humanity and Bondye, a transcendent creator divinity. Vodouists believe that over a thousand lwa exist, the names of at least 232 of which are recorded. Each lwa has its own personality and is associated with specific colors and objects. Many of them are equated with specific Roman Catholic saints on the basis of similar characteristics or shared symbols. The lwa are divided into different groups, known as nanchon (nations), the most notable of which are the Petwo and the Rada. According to Vodou belief, the lwa communicate with humans through dreams and divination, and in turn are given offerings, including sacrificed animals. Vodou teaches that during ceremonies, the lwa possess specific practitioners, who during the possession are considered the chwal (horse) of the lwa. Through possessing an individual, Vodouists believe, the lwa can communicate with other humans, offering advice, admonishment, or healing

>During the Atlantic slave trade of the 16th to 19th centuries, enslaved West Africans brought their traditional religions with them. In the French colony of Saint-Domingue, which became the republic of Haiti in the early 19th century, the diasporic religion of Vodou emerged amid the mixing of different West African traditional religions and the influence of the French colonists' Roman Catholicism

posts.com:
The Japanese government went all-out after World War II to promote a positive image of Japanese society and culture to Westerners and the world. In this, they were initially much assisted by the US government, which was at pains to ensure the country would not end up part of the Communist bloc. But in any case, the PR effort to clean up Japan's image had the following benefits for Japan:

1) This helped to ease lingering bitterness, resentment and mistrust over the atrocities and ill-treatment Europeans and North Americans in Asia suffered at the hands of the Japanese during the war years, by ensuring that the next generation had a more positive attitude towards their country.

2) This helped ensure Japan American protection from its enemies, and enabled the country to avoid the sort of massive military spending that would otherwise have been necessary to secure the country's defence, facilitating higher welfare spending.

3) This enabled Japan to get involved in direct lobbying of US politicians without the sort of backlash that might otherwise have ensued. For example, in the 1970s, Toshiba facilitated the transfer of advanced submarine propeller technology to the USSR, something which greatly advanced Soviet attack capabilities, and gravely damaged US interests. Only the perception of Japan as a generally "friendly" country enabled Japanese lobbyists to urge American lawmakers in the aftermath not to severely punish Toshiba and Japan in the interest of maintaining good US-Japan relations.

In 1832, a 150-ton Japanese rice transport blew off course, losing its mast and rudder, and was seaworthy enough to drift for 14 months to Washington State with three survivors. By the 1870s British-built Japanese ships were menacing Taiwan and Korea. No. Our conscience and the moral precepts afforded by nature likewise act to restrain those impulses, alongside the existence of law enforcement, various modes of surveillance, and the implicit sanctions that are enforced against maladaptive or antisocial individuals in society (i.e. lunch table, ostracism, blacklisting, etc.) For the Christian, however, it is the additional element of our Savior having commanded us to observe all that He has said, and our desire to serve and worship Him in holiness and thanksgiving, that impels a stricter conformity to the law (whether Biblical or manmade). Of course, some antinomians denominations may argue against the binding validity of the law as a rule for life, but that goes against the very words of Christ and of His apostles.

It seems to me that it is in fact unbelievers who have less of an incentive to be law abiding citizens, seeing as they deny the universality of moral obligations and the inevitable visitation of justice even to those malefactors who operate covertly. It follows that apart from a mature notion of maintaining social harmony and cohesion, a belief scarcely present in the youth of today, or a arbitrary commitment to particular ethical precepts, the unbeliever would only obey rules and statutes only insofar as he perceives a greater likelihood of getting caught by human authorities in violating them. Likewise, he perceives a net benefit accruing to himself in conforming his behavior to the expected norms of society. Classical carrot and stick behavior.

So, then, the Christian has far more reason to act rightly than the heathen. Your thoughts, OP?

>>14545042
You don't seem to realize how far behind the rest of the world was. In the 15th century and early 16th century Italian mathematicians solved a flurry of centuries old problems that stumped the Greeks and the Indian and Muslim world, for example they dabbled in cubic equations but it wasn't until Ferro and Tartaglia that a complete solution was found. There were also technical innovations, if China was "wild", Europe during the late middle ages and renaissance must have been a "heckin' beast fr fr", for example France had water powered saw mills in the 14th century, Flemish weavers invented new vertical looms that tripled productivity, Flemish forges developed methods of carburizing or decarburizing iron and imported low impurity ore from far off places to produce high quality steel. When Europe reached India and China they only had a handful of innovations the Europeans did not, usually related to things Europe did not have like cotton or lacquer.

Further you vastly overinflate the significance of colonialism. The industrial revolution was in full swing in Britain at the turn of the 18th century with Isaac Newton and the first economically productive steam engines pumping water out of mines, before this point most goods from the colonies were spices and precious metals, the former is a luxury, the latter lost much of its value due to inflation. Aztec gold and silver was in fact spent on an invasion of England, though I would not actually consider this important in the larger scale of things. The overwhelming majority of economic activity and technological development was taking place in Europe and continued to be even in the industrial revolution when cotton and others goods from the colonies had a significant impact, but by this time the scientific underpinnings of the industrial revolution were already there.

If you stop looking at it in terms of truisms and flesh out your analysis a little, your narrative is highly distorted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14546291
The most likely theory is that they lived between Pripet marshes and Carpathians(Podolia etc.). Archaeology hints towards south of this range, but the marshes were poorly surveyed and given Chernobyl and the current war it won't change anytime soon, not to mention that the local microclimate makes preservation of artifacts there harder, so we may be dealing with discovery bias. The area in abstract makes sense because:
1. Assuming they didn't cross mountain ranges as they've migrated, the distance they could cover between the collapse of the hunnic empire and their first mentions by byzantines is proportional with the distance between it and the earliest finds of slavic like pottery in the Czech Republic.
2. The area is poorly known by the Romans, meaning that if you're looking for some kind of proto-slavs that should be somewhere but are never mentioned that is a good place to look for.
3. They must have had some contact with some of the steppe Iranians like Sarmatians or Scythians which would make sense there, but wouldn't make sense closer to the Baltic.
4. The "forest Scythians" Herodotus mentions that sometimes are associated with slavs would have to live exactly there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One hundred fifty are besieged by five thousand;
Not only the provisions but the ammunition is all gone.
Thirty-two men hear the news and hurry to the scene.
The heavy strokes of their sabers lead them into the fortress, through the ranks of the enemy to see
The commander of the fortress wet with blood,
And his men reeling against the walls with exhaustion but with swords in hand.
Now comes the dauntless South Carolinian,
Knowing that if he does not answer duty's call, disgrace and shame will be his.
Returning he rides into the siege on a white charger,
Salutes the besieged with a smile, and says, "We die together."
They bind up their wounds and fight in higher spirits.
Speak not of the bravery of Chang Hsun at Suiyang, for here the one hundred and eighty-two corpses were laid; not one surrendered.
The people of the twenty-four states get inspiration thereby,
And learn for the first time that unanimous cooperation is superior to geographical advantage.
Why should they be mourned? For the dauntless, it is not a pain but a pleasure to cover an obstruction miles long.
Lo! the mouth of the river once occupied by the enemy is in the possession of the T' ang!
Now I am on a journey, far away from my home across the ocean.
I have come to San Antonio, where there are bushes of the graceful oleander.
And, as in a dream, I wonder if this is the very spot where that dreadful bloodshed took place in years gone by.
You do not see Chang Hsun, Hsu Yuan, and Nan Chiyun (David Crockett, Bowie, and Bonham)
But their fame, like the blossom's fragrance, is still in the air.
The custom of the West does not necessarily condemn surrender.
Why? We have never heard of a commander destroyed,
But here in the state of Texas, we see one (Travis).
In spirit there is not a distinction between East and West.
You need not wonder, then, if I drink a toast to your memory!
I have brought a well-polished stone from Japan,
And commemorate your heroic deeds with this humble inscription.

志賀重昂

>>14544295
DNA tests have been very useful for confirming or refuting historical. Thanks to them, we know that the Anglo-Saxon invasion of England wasn’t a total replacement of the celts. There was a lot of mixing. But then it also showed that there was a lot of NW French admixture that also needs to be accounted for.
As for one’s own ancestry, it’s useful to help fill in some blanks. However, they’re not perfect. For instance, a recent ancestry DNA update started giving me a ton of weird shit that not totally accurate; it overlaps certain areas. For instance, it reads some of my British DNA as Scandinavian, but that can’t possibly be accurate based on my extensive family tree. It’s accurate in a sense that the British overlap greatly with Scandinavians, but I don’t have any ancestors from the past 200-300 years from Scandinavia. It would be retarded to say I’m at all Scandinavian.
For personal ancestry, creating a family tree is truly the best and only way to go to be certain of anything. Though DNA helps show that I’m certainly English and Ulster Scottish rather than Irish and Welsh.

It depends on the time period and who you were. In the grand scheme of things? Pretty alright? I actually have a PhD in Ottoman history. You are going to get a lot of mingy nationalist posts talking about how awful it was - while I am not going to pretend the Ottoman Empire was perfect you should ignore these. The Ottomans are just an easy scapegoat for problems because they don't exist. Most slavic nations, the greeks, etc. Their issues stem from post-Ottoman shenigans, corruption, and larger European politics. But, it is easy to blame the dead empire than shake fists at people who might actually get mad at you. You'll get some people going for the epic owning Islam take - these can also be ignored. This is not a good place to ask this if you want genuine responses. I will try my best though to give you a very direct and (overly) simple take: As a point of fact despite the work of Suraiya Faroqhi and others our knowledge of the common person in the Ottoman empire is pretty poor. The records don't show you much about their actual lived experience, you have a metric ton of data from a government/elite perspective, but common people are kind of just looked down on and ignored. They come up in court sicils and other things from time to time, but, we know more about Elite people, in major cities then we do about anything else. (Though again, time and place matter immensely) most accounts you'd find from Europeans and others would say - it would have been pretty damn good to be an elite most of the time, and pretty okay to good to be a common person.

The Stonehenge Free Festival was a British free festival from 1974 to 1984 held at the prehistoric monument Stonehenge in England during the month of June, and culminating with the summer solstice on or near 21 June. It emerged as the major free festival in the calendar after the violent suppression of the Windsor Free Festival in August 1974, with Wally Hope providing the impetus for its founding, and was itself violently suppressed in 1985 in the Battle of the Beanfield, with no free festival held at Stonehenge since although people have been allowed to gather at the stones again for the solstice since 1999.

By the 1980s, the festival had grown to be a major event, attracting up to 30,000 people in 1984. The festival attendees were branded as hippies by the British press. This, along with the open drug use and sale, contributed to the increase in restrictions on access to Stonehenge, and fences were erected around the stones in 1977. The same year, police resurrected a moribund law against driving over grassland in order to levy fines against festival goers in motorised transport. By 1984 police-festival relations were relaxed with only a nominal police presence required. Tabernacle of G-D being crushed since 1985.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14546679
>Geolibertarianism is a political and economic ideology that integrates libertarianism with Georgism. It favors a taxation system based (as in Georgism) on income derived from land and natural resources instead of on labor, coupled with a minimalist model of government, as in libertarianism.

>Geolibertarians recognize the right to private ownership of land, but only if fair recompense is paid to the community for the loss of access to that land. Some geolibertarians broaden out the tax base to include resource depletion, environmental damage, and other ancillaries to land use.

>A succinct summary of this philosophy can be found in Thomas Paine's 1797 pamphlet Agrarian Justice: "Men did not make the earth. It is the value of the improvements only, and not the earth itself, that is individual property. Every proprietor owes to the community a ground rent for the land which he holds".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Geolibertarians maintain that geographical space and raw natural resources—any assets that qualify as land by economic definition—are rivalrous goods to be considered common property, or more accurately unowned, which all individuals share an equal human right to access, not capital wealth to be privatized fully and absolutely. Therefore, landholders ought to pay compensation according to the rental value set by the free market, absent any improvements, to the community for the civil right of usufruct (that is, legally recognized exclusive possession with restrictions on property abuse) or otherwise fee simple title with no such restrictions. Ideally, the taxing of a site would be administered only after it has been determined that the privately captured economic rent from the land exceeds the title-holder's equal share of total land value in the jurisdiction.

On this proposal, rent is collected not for the mere occupancy or use of land, as neither the community nor the state rightfully owns the commons, but rather as an objectively assessed indemnity due for the legal right to exclude others from that land. Some geolibertarians also support Pigovian taxes on pollution and severance taxes to regulate natural resource depletion and compensatory fees with ancillary positive environmental effects on activities which negatively impact land values. They take the standard right-libertarian position that each individual is naturally entitled to the fruits of their labor as exclusive private property as opposed to produced goods being owned collectively by society or by the government acting to represent society, and that a person's "labor, wages, and the products of labor" should not be taxed. Along with non-Georgists in the libertarian movement, they also advocate the law of equal liberty, supporting "full civil liberties, with no crimes unless there are victims who have been invaded."[1]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Geolibertarians are generally influenced by the Georgist single tax movement of the late-19th and early-20th centuries, but the ideas behind it pre-date Henry George and can be found in different forms in the political writings of John Locke, the early agrarian socialism of English True Levellers or Diggers such as Gerrard Winstanley, the French Physiocrats (especially Quesnay and Turgot), British classical economists Adam Smith and David Ricardo, French liberal economists Jean-Baptiste Say and Frédéric Bastiat, American Revolutionary writers Thomas Jefferson and Thomas Paine, English Radical land reformer Thomas Spence, American individualist anarchists Lysander Spooner and Benjamin Tucker, as well as British classical liberal philosophers John Stuart Mill and Herbert Spencer. Prominent geolibertarians since George have included Old Right social critics Albert Jay Nock and Frank Chodorov. Other libertarians who have expressed support for the land value tax as an incremental reform include Milton Friedman, Karl Hess, John Hospers and United States Libertarian Party co-founder David Nolan.[2]

I guess technological backwardness and golden liberty of boyars that were bribed by enemy powers also weakened PLC a lot.
From ethnic Lithuanian standpoint the problem was also our general backwardness that allowed for foreign cultural influence to spread, polonization took root among aristocracy (even if they called themselves Lithuanians and defended their sovereignty because it was the source of their power) and among city dwellers and lower nobility, boyars (especially mid tier boyars), because they wanted privileges that Polish boyars had, looked up to them culturally and adapted their language and other customs in greater or lesser form.
Also, serfdom, that meant that peasantry couldn't really form its own cultural trends, Paganism was slowly extinguished or adapted and Christianity needed to be adapted over few centuries. But maybe that also saved us from total assimilation, because serfs were insulated from larger global and local trends. We might have ended up as Irish then, speaking mostly in Polish as they do in English.
Not really my take, but it's one made by Polish Lithuanian noble, lawyer.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michał_Pius_Römer
But I think it's a good take.

>>14546230
the goal of buddhism is to end suffering
the claim of the buddha is that suffering is conditioned, and that suffering ceases once the condition of the arising of suffering is killed
to kill
the claim of the buddha is also that the condition of suffering is also conditioned, in fact there is a whole chain of conditions
it turns out that ''desire'' is part of the chain of the conditions of the arising of suffering

In order to trigger the chain reaction to kill suffering, you do not need desire.
There is no use of any ''will'' in buddhism to kill suffering.

In buddhism you can't fight the chain reaction, whether you like it or not, whether you want it or not.

To jump start the killing of suffering you can use desire, but this wont be needed to reach the end.

And nobody has the ''desire to end desire'', because that's knowing the ending before even starting, and non-enlightened people don't even know what ''ending desire'' feels like anyway.

The way to start is really to want to end suffering, then at partial enlightenment, the propulsion is done thru right view, and the day to day life is being annoyed by 1/ the sensual inputs and desiring to get away from the cancerous sensations (which is done by meditation, because meditation is always more pleasing than sensuality, but meditation is still suffering) 2/ the general meta framework that any meaningful existence (ie even the gods and whatever happens in meditation) is tainted by suffering

“Of special interest is also the reference to the bishop of Rome as the “archbishop of all the churches.” The pertinent question for the inquirer, upon reading such a title, concerns the kind of authority which was possessed by an archbishop. While varying jurisdictional arrangements with varying degrees of primatial power have been present in different times and regions, the intrinsic character of primacy is defined in Apostolic Canon 34: “The bishops of every nation must acknowledge him who is first among them and account him as their head, and do nothing of consequence without his consent… But neither let him who is the first do anything without the consent of all; for so there will be unanimity, and God will be glorified through the Lord in the Holy Spirit.” To speak of the Pope of Rome as the archbishop of all the churches cannot, then, be equated without consideration to his having ordinary and immediate jurisdiction over all the Churches. Indeed, the context of the Council, given the critical analysis of St. Leo’s Tome by the Council Fathers, suggests something more like that described in the Apostolic Canons, where primatial and collegial authority are both necessary for the Council’s being what it is.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14545660
>Why link me to a website for some cult organization

Cult organization? Nonsense.

For those who may be following this discussion, here is what this anon calls a "cult organization":

https://www.churchfathers.org/the-real-presence

That is, he characterizes a website that collects the words of the early Church Fathers as a cult.

>in your own words
I did tell you in my own words. You responded with your words. Etc. It is a bootless argument because it is plain that I'm not going to change your mind, and a certainty that you shall not change mine.

But for any third-party observers, I will respond in brief to your remarks on transubstantiation.

The doctrine of transubstantiation is implicit in Christ's words at the Last Supper: He holds what appears to be a piece of bread, and says "This is My Body."

He doesn't say "This contains my body," or "This symbolizes my body," or "My spiritual body accompanies this when a believer eats it."

Rather He says: This IS My Body.

The doctrine is implicit in the teaching of the Fathers as early as Ignatius of Antioch, circa 115 AD: "The Eucharist IS the flesh of our Savior Jesus Christ."

Now the Eucharist, in appearance, is a piece of bread -- yet Ignatius says it *is* the flesh of Christ.

That is what transubstantiation means, that is what transubstantiation is.

Ignatius does not speak of bread which contains Christ's flesh (as in Luther's consubstantiation), or a mere spiritual presence, as per Calvin.

No. According to Ignatius, "The Eucharist IS the flesh of our Savior Jesus Christ."

Likewise Augustine: "Christ bore Himself in His hands, when He offered His body saying: 'this is my body.'"

That is the gist of the meaning of transubstantiation. Now, to explain the doctrine of the Trinity that was implicit, although not expressly stated or explained, in Scripture, the early Church Fathers used the language of Greek philosophy. Likewise St. Thomas in explaining the nature of Christ's presence in the Eucharist.

The New Testament beyond the Gospels was manifested in due time like it says in Titus 1:1-3. Paul's epistles were written by revelation of Jesus Christ and that occurred roughly during the timespan from 49 to 67 AD, other books had a roughly similar timeline. The last book that was given by inspiration was to John on the isle of Patmos near the end of the century, and the revelations that he received were generally 15-25 years after the rest. >The point is, I am asking on what basis you consider baptism to violate what’s being taught in Ephesians 2:8-9
I don't think you understand. The point here is that believing, as it says in John 6:47 – "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me hath everlasting life." – believing in the Lord Jesus is the gift of God. As it says in Ephesians 2:8-9, by grace are we saved through faith, and that not of ourselves, it is the gift of God, not of works, lest any man should boast. So, the act of acknowledgement does not mean we are trusting in any of our own works. Because again, salvation is not of ourselves, and not of works. This answers the alleged objection in the first question here: >>14546368

So then getting back to the question, the faith that the Bible speaks of is the reason for salvation - not anything that is of ourselves. So it cannot be characterized as trusting in one's own work then, as it is not a work. This faith is mentioned in Colossians 2:12 and throughout Scripture (cf Ps. 32:5, etc.) Baptism, again, according to 1 Peter 3:21, is a figure of that which saves us; that which saves us is the actual Resurrection of our Savior and Lord. So according to the Bible, baptism is not that which saves us, but it actually represents this same thing. Because of this, it is shown not to be that which saves us, as stated in 1 Peter 3:21.

It is rather "the answer of a good conscience toward God." This characterizes baptism as something that is done willingly, because it is an "answer" of something that is on their "conscience." So, while such a thing is a matter of obedience to the truth, it is not the actual salvific factor for whether a person is saved. That's to say, it doesn't "violate" Eph. 2:8-9. But to say that it, or any good work outside of Christ's sacrifice, is the "cause of salvation," does in fact contradict it. Of course according to Ephesians 2:10, good works are to be done. And Biblical baptism doesn't "violate" anything in itself.

The relations between China and Oman in the eleventh to fifteenth centuries can be witnessed in the existence of Omani names in Chinese literature from this époque. The Manchus put civilian Mongols under a brutal apartheid system.

>19On the other hand, this ethnically-unified Mongolia was not to be a unitary political entity.10 Instead, they were subdivided into numerous smaller units, from aimag (tribes) and chuulgan (leagues) to hoshuun (banners). The six leagues of inner jasag (later known as Inner Mongolia) were divided into 49 banners, and the Khalkha (later known as Outer Mongolia) were divided into 81 banners. There were also numerous other banners outside the two large entities. Borders were demarcated and policed between tribes, leagues and even between banners. Karun (M. Haruul, C. Kalun) border control stations were set up along borders, and stone cairns called oboo were built between karuns. At strategic places, each karun was manned by 30–40 soldiers from Manchu garrison armies stationed in Suiyuan, Ningxia, Uliastai and other places; they would patrol along the border every day to the oboo between karuns, where they exchanged information with patrols from the other karun. This was called khaich yavakh, scissor-walking, a metaphor implying that the soldiers were cutting the borderline like scissors, making a radical partition. These karuns and oboos would be checked by Manchu garrison generals once a month and they would be inspected by officials from the Lifan Yuan in Beijing occasionally. No tribal, league, or banner nobles and subjects were permitted to cross banner borders, nor were they allowed to marry across banners without authorization. The karun guards would make their record every day and the inspection report would be sent to Beijing regularly (Baoyinchaoketu 2003).

>Punishment was severe for any violations of borders, trespassing either into “neidi”, that is, inland China, or into other’s territory. For instance, Daqing Huidian Shili, published in the twenty-third year of Jiaqing reign (1814), recorded the following: “Originally, should there be border violations from Mongolia, a prince would be fined 10 horses, zasag, beile, beizi, and gong 7 horses, taiji five horses, and commoner, a cattle”. By the second decade of the nineteenth century, the fine had been increased tenfold for aristocrats, and a commoner would lose all his property, including himself, which would be awarded to the whistle-blower (Huidianguan 2006: vol. 979, pp. 237–39). >21Such stringent prohibition of trespassing borders was to mould a divided unity of the Mongols under the Qing gurun or state. All Mongols were to identify with the Qing state, not as a politically unified nation (ulus), but through the banner system. It was intended to prevent the Mongols from realigning with each other and challenging the Qing, as it categorically prohibited princes from conquering each other, which was the classical mode for the rise of power among the nomads. Consolidation of the banner administrative system was designed to ensure political stability in the backyard of the Qing.

* Petty bourgeois socialism - Capitalism without capitalists (Example: USSR from 1957-1964 under Khrushchevite era)
* Fascism - monarchy without the monarch, corporatist (based off the Canadian Christian model) class collaborationist populist one party state using revolutionary energy for violence in order to push society back to feudalism (Examples: Nazi Germany / Fascist Italy)

posts.com:
>>14543404
Despite the huge size of the complex most residents had no idea what was going on. In many ways they had it better than a lot of Poles in other parts of Poland. The huge number of SS personnel and other German settlers required servants and many residents found employment and protection that way. My grandmother was a teenage girl during the war and she became a maid for a family of German settlers who actually treated her well, giving her all sorts of luxury items for her service. On the flipside a portion of the population was expelled to make space for the camp and some residents became more aware or less complicit than others and were smuggling medicine and food inside the camp or helping forced laborers escape.
Generally speaking the public was unaware of what was going on inside the camp until the later stages of the war. From 1942 to 1944 a lot of escapees wrote reports that eventually made their way to the Home Army, then the Polish government in exile, then the Allied governments and finally the press. This increased awareness eventually led Jewish communities in the US and Britain to advocate for bombing campaigns against the camp's railway infrastructure but the only raid that actually took place was against IG Farben works at the Monowitz subcamp

>>14543443
Auschwitz II originally started off as a POW camp, but it's purpose quickly changed
It wasn't a pure extermination camp in a sense that everyone who ended up at Birkenau would be gassed, but rather it served as both a giant distribution centre for the Reich's slave labor system as well as an extermination place for those who were deemed too useless to be a slave laborer. Many people (mainly Poles) were in Birkenau only for transit purposes. Out of those who remained not all of them were killed outright as the Auschwitz complex had its own labor requirements. Inmates were used to expand the camp, guard each other, sort through people's personal belongings or for work in various subcamps. So in this sense it wasn't a pure extermination camp, but industrial killing was without a shadow of a doubt one of Birkenau's functions

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No, People could moved around quite a lot even during the bronze age, of course the speeds are significantly more limited and the level of stability affects things too, but unless you were tied in one way or the other, you could end up traveling a lot looking for job opportunities, such for example people involved construction could move seeking employment on big projects happening elsewhere, a craftsman might seek, or even be requested
, a different place to exercise his craft.

Horses and donkeys were very important, but more important that were rivers which were basicaly highways for inland people and cargo transport. People who traveled further than their neigborhood would do so through an intinerary, which is basicaly a sequence of towns which he should follow to reach some specific location

>>14546053
While this photo makes it seem like AA 191 was merely perpendicular to the ground, in reality it flipped almost upside down by impact. Passengers on the right side would have seen the engine falling off out the window and the shock and vibration from it detaching would have been felt through the entire structure of the plane. It's almost nightmarish to imagine being inside that plane.

Had the crew known what was happening they could have kicked the remaining engines to full throttle but a plane with a missing engine, wing damage, ripped wires, and fuel spilling out was not likely to have much prospect of landing safely.

Can we have a thread on this? This is a topic that is not that is normally discussed due to Albania being largely regarded as a "literal who" tier country. But to sum it all up in tl;dr fashion:

* Albania and China, while both strong allies of the USSR, became increasingly hostile towards the USSR, especially after 1956 secret speech and the 1957 Khrushchevite coup. The anti-revisionist faction the Marxist-Leninist, while not hostile originally to de-Stalinization, became increasingly opposed as it became clear that Khrushchev was a revisionist and capitalist roader who restored capitalism in the USSR by 1957.
* With Soviet aid cut off the Albania and China, both had to strongly cooperate in terms of economic and and military alliance
* Albania and China's isolation only increased with the Indonesian mass killings of 1965–66 of the Communist Party of Indonesia, that was highly supportive of China position in the Cold War.
* Both Albania and China strongly opposed the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia on grounds of Soviet social imperialism. This also lead to Albania formally leaving the Warsaw Pact.
* Decline in relations between Albania and China from 1972 to 1978. In 1978, Deng Xiaoping began implementing capitalist reforms that brought an end to socialism in China.
